Table 4 Catalyst Specific surfacearea (m2/g) Pore volume(cm3/g) Pore diameter (nm) C (%) N (%) H (%) γ-Al2O3 150 0.606 14.1 0.04 0.06 0.33 Rh/γ-Al2O3-Fresh 141 0.730 17.0 0.08 0.10 0.45 Rh/γ-Al2O3-Used 125 0.649 15.9 8.09 2.30 1.51 Rh/γ-Al2O3-Used-D 136 0.708 17.0 0.47 0.24 0.58 A novel and green synthesis of methylcyclohexane diisocyanate: Reaction properties, deactivation and regeneration of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in benzene ring selective hydrogenation Yucong Song Data curation Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Xiaoshu Ding Investigation Formal analysis Writing – review & editing ⁎ Fang Li Investigation Validation Dongsheng Zhang Investigation Validation Xinqiang Zhao Conceptualization Funding acquisition Validation Yanji Wang Conceptualization Methodology Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ Hebei Provincial Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Technology and High Efficient Energy Saving, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China Hebei Provincial Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Technology and High Efficient Energy Saving, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China Hebei Provincial Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Technology and High Efficient Energy Saving, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Methylcyclohexane diisocyanate (HTDI) is the core raw material for the synthesis of high-grade polyurethane. Aiming at the problems existing environmental pollution and safety risks in the phosgene process, a novel and green synthesis route of HTDI was proposed. We studied the catalytic hydrogenation of dimethyl toluene dicarbamate (TDC) benzene ring to methyl cyclohexyldicarbamate (HTDC) in this novel route. The effects of metal active components, supports and metal Rh loadings on the catalytic performance were investigated. It was found that the supported Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst had excellent catalytic activity and selectivity. The yield of HTDC was close to 100 % at 100 °C under 3 MPa hydrogen pressure. However, the catalyst was deactivated seriously after the reaction. The organic matter adsorbed on the catalyst surface and covered the active metal was the main reason for the catalyst deactivation. Fortunately, the deactivated catalyst could be regenerated by solvent washing and high temperature calcination. Graphical Abstract A Novel and Green Reaction Pathway for the Synthesis of HTDI ga1 Keywords Green synthesis Benzene ring Catalytic hydrogenation Regeneration Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Toluene diisocyanate (TDI) is an important basic raw material for the synthesis of polyurethane materials, which is mainly used in polyurethane flexible foams, polyurethane elastomers, coatings, adhesives and other fields [1–3]. Methylcyclohexane diisocyanate (HTDI), the benzene ring hydrogenation product of TDI, is a kind of alicyclic diisocyanate. Since the benzene ring in the TDI molecule is replaced by a six-membered aliphatic ring, the polyurethane product prepared from it has excellent characteristics, such as non-yellowing, light stability, weather resistance and high mechanical properties, so it is the core raw material for the production of high-grade polyurethane. In addition, HTDI can also be used to synthesize safe and stable free radical photoinitiators for the production of UV curing adhesives, coatings and inks. [4]. Fluorinated carbamate, which is synthesized by HTDI, can be used to the manufacture of optical components, especially holographic photopolymers [5]. At present, the synthesis of HTDI adopts the phosgene process, which is divided into two steps: catalytic hydrogenation of 2,4-toluenediamine (TDA) to 1-methyl-2,4-cyclohexanediamine (MCHD), and phosgenation of MCHD to obtain HTDI [6]. Among them, the hydrogenation of TDA to MCHD has some potential safety risks such as the direct use of hydrogen, high pressure operation and exothermic reaction. Phosgene, a reaction raw material for synthesizing HTDI with MCHD, is a highly toxic chemical, which has serious safety risks in production, storage, transportation and use, and the by-product hydrochloric acid of the reaction corrodes equipment and pollutes the environment. In view of the serious environmental and safety problems in the process of producing HTDI by phosgene process, a novel and green route was proposed for the synthesis of HTDI, as shown in Fig. 1. This novel reaction paths include: the methoxycarbonylation of TDA with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) to synthesize dimethyl toluene dicarbamate (TDC) (step I), the benzene ring hydrogenation of TDC by H2 to produce methyl cyclohexyldicarbamate (HTDC) (step II), and the decomposition of HTDC to HTDI (step III). This path has the following inherent security characteristics: (a) Using dimethyl carbonate instead of phosgene as a green reagent; (b) The route is a "zero emission" process: by-product methanol of methoxyl carbonylation and decomposition reaction was recycled for the synthesis of raw material DMC. We have systematically studied the methoxycarbonylation of TDA with dimethyl carbonate in the first step (I) of the pathway [7–10]. This paper reports the research results of the second step (II) the catalytic hydrogenation of TDC benzene ring to HTDC. There were very few studies focusing on the selective hydrogenation of TDC benzene ring to HTDC. Malz and Greenfield [11,12] used Rh/C catalyst and isopropanol as solvent to react at room temperature and under hydrogen pressure of 3.5–5.5 MPa for 8 h, and the yield of HTDC was 99.5 %. Unfortunately, there are no reports on the reuse and deactivation—regeneration performance of catalysts required for industrialization. Although there were few researches on the benzene ring selective hydrogenation of methyl carbamate retained, researchers have investigated the catalysts used in the selective hydrogenation reaction system of benzene ring with different substituents. Catalytic reaction systems, including hydrogenation of aromatic amines to alicyclic amines [13,14], aromatic formates to alicyclic formates [15–17], polystyrene to poly(cyclohexylethylene) [18,19], biphenyl to cyclohexylbenzene [20,21], and bisphenol A to hydrogenated bisphenol-A [22,23], were studied. The selective hydrogenation of benzene rings with retained substituent groups is an extremely important reaction in the chemical industry. It can not only eliminates the potential health hazards caused by phenyl derivatives containing benzene rings, but also plays an important role in the formation of various aliphatic compounds, and such substances are also important fine chemicals that have been widely used as important intermediates in pharmaceuticals and pesticides, or as key starting materials for the synthesis of dyes, resins and polymers [24–27]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Rhodium (III) chloride hydrate (RhCl3·xH2O) was purchased from Beijing Innochem Technology Co., Ltd (China). Ruthenium (III) chloride hydrate (RuCl3·xH2O), chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O) and palladium chloride (PdCl2) were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). Ammonia was produced by Tianjin University Kewei Company. (China). Active carbon was supplied by Shanghai Huiheda Investment Management Co., Ltd. (China). Aluminium oxide, zirconium dioxide, ceria and dimethyl carbonate were produced by Aladdin Industrial Co. (China). Isopropanol, methyl acetate and tetrahydrofuran were purchased from Tianjin Komiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). HZSM-5 molecular sieve Si/Al = 25) were supplied by Nankai University Catalyst Factory. (China). All reagents were of analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. Hydrogen and nitrogen were purchased from Tianjin Sizhi Gas Co., Ltd. (China). 2.2 Catalyst preparation A series of Rh (Ru, Pt, Pd)/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by equal volume impregnation method. Add a certain concentration of RhCl3·xH2O (RuCl3·xH2O, H2PtCl6·6H2O, PdCl2) aqueous solution (PdCl2 was dissolved in ammonia) dropwise into a certain amount of γ-Al2O3, immersed for 24 h, dried in an oven at 110 °C for 6 h, calcined in a muffle furnace at 450 °C for 4 h, and then reduced in a tube furnace under a flow of 80 mL/80 mL H2/N2 at 300 °C for 3 h to obtain Rh(Ru, Pt, Pd)/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The preparation method of Rh catalyst supported by other different supports, including activated carbon, ZrO2, CeO2 and HZSM-5 was the same as above. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystallographic structure of the samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Rigaku Dmax 2500PC X-ray diffractometer and Cu-Kα radiation (V = 40 kV, I = 40 mA), employing a scan step of 0.2° in the 2θ range of 10–90°. The textural properties of catalysts including specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter analysis were measured by an ASAP 2020 M+C specific surface and porosity analyzer. Weigh about 0.2 g of sample previously degassed under vacuum at 150 °C for 4 h to remove impurities adsorbed on the surface; Then, N2 adsorption and desorption were measured in a liquid nitrogen atmosphere. The specific surface area of the sample was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the pore volume and pore diameter were determined by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) desorption method. The morphology and dispersion of the Rhodium nanoparticles were examined using an FEI Talos F200S field emission high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM). The samples were ultrasonically dispersed in anhydrous ethanol, and then a small amount of liquid was added dropwise onto a copper mesh covered with an ultra-thin carbon film and dried with an infrared lamp. Elemental analysis (EA) was performed on a Flash EA 1112 automatic elemental analyzer. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) was used to determine the actual concentrations of Rhodium in the studied samples. The thermal stability of catalysts was performed on the TA-SDT Q600 instrument. 5–8 mg samples were weighed and slowly moved into the Al2O3 crucible, and heated to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 and a flow rate of 100 mL·min−1 under air atmosphere. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer with an Al Kα X-ray radiation, which was used to analyze the surface chemical states of the catalysts. The C 1s signal at 284.8 eV from adventitious carbon was used as reference to correct the effect of surface charge. The Rh metal dispersion was determined by using pulsed CO chemisorption at 25 °C (AutoChem1 II 2920). Samples were firstly degassed at 300 °C in Argon (Ar, 99.999 %) at the flow rate of 80 mL/min for 60 min. After that, samples were reduced under the 50 % H2 flow mixed with Ar, then cooled to 25 °C and use He air flow (50 mL/min) purge to remove the surface H2, the final adsorption with CO gas until saturated. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation and product analysis The catalytic hydrogenation of TDC benzene ring was carried out in a 100 mL autoclave. The product was analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (Waters e2695) and quantified by external standard method. The chromatographic column was Agilent ZORBAX Eclipse XDB-C18 (4.6 ×250 mm, 5 µm), the column temperature was 35 °C, the sample size was 15 μL, the detector was evaporative light detector (Alltech 2000ES), the mobile phase was methanol/water = 50/50 (vol. %), the flow rate was 0.6 mL·min−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Solvent selection based on simplified separation process In the liquid-phase hydrogenation reaction, solvents have different dissolution properties and transport capacities for the substrate and hydrogen. To this end, DMC, isopropanol, methyl acetate and tetrahydrofuran were used as solvents respectively to investigate the effect of different solvents on the performance of Rh/γ-Al2O3 in the catalytic hydrogenation of TDC benzene ring to HTDC. The results are shown in Fig. 2. It can be seen that with 5 %Rh/γ-Al2O3 as catalyst, under the condition of reaction temperature of 100 ℃ and hydrogen pressure of 3 MPa, the reaction rate was the fastest in methyl acetate and the yield of HTDC was close to 100 % after 50 min. It took 65 min and 115 min for isopropanol and DMC to approach 100 % yield, respectively. However, there was little catalytic activity in tetrahydrofuran. The possible reason is that DMC, isopropyl alcohol and methyl acetate are protic solvents with strong proton donor abilities, that is, the ability to transmit hydrogen. The formation of hydrogen bonds with TDC can reduce the activation energy of the catalytic reaction, thereby increasing the catalytic reaction rate. Tetrahydrofuran is an aprotic solvent, and the solvent molecules will be adsorbed to the active sites of the catalyst, thus occupying the catalytic active sites and inhibiting the hydrogenation reaction of TDC molecules. It can be considered that the solubility of the solvent and the strength of hydrogen bonding with TDC jointly affect the reaction performance. In the green and intrinsic safety reaction pathway for the synthesis of HTDI (Fig. 1), TDC was synthesized from TDA and DMC (step I), with DMC serving as both reactant and solvent. In order to simplify separation units, DMC was still used as the solvent in TDC benzene ring hydrogenation to synthesize HTDC (step II), so that the reaction liquid synthesized from TDC could be directly benzene ring hydrogenation to HTDC without additional separation section, which provided the basis for the establishment of continuous flow reaction process. 3.2 Benzene ring hydrogenation performance of metal components The effects of different metal active components (Rh, Ru, Pt, and Pd) on the γ-Al2O3 (activated carbon) carrier with a loading of 5 % on the reaction performance of TDC benzene ring hydrogenation to HTDC were investigated, as listed in Table 1. It can be seen that the TDC conversion and product selectivity of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst were close to 100 % at 100 ℃, 3 MPa and 3 h, but other active component catalysts had almost no catalytic activity. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of catalysts with different metal active components supported on the support of γ-Al2O3. It can be seen that the Pt/γ-Al2O3, Ru/γ-Al2O3 and Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts had diffraction peaks of their corresponding metals. Interestingly, no obvious characteristic diffraction peaks of Rh were observed over the Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, indicating that the Rh species supported on γ-Al2O3 were highly dispersed or had a small particle size, which may be one of the reasons for the better performance of Rh as an active component. In addition, the crystal grains of Pt, Ru, Pd on the surface of the γ-Al2O3 carrier were large, which was also the reason for its inactivity. 3.3 Effect of support on the performance of Rh catalyst for benzene ring hydrogenation The texture properties, Rh loadings and the reaction performance of TDC hydrogenation to HTDC of catalysts with different supports are shown in Table 2. The benzene ring hydrogenation performance of the Rh catalyst was not only significantly affected by the texture properties of the support but also the Rh loading. When γ-Al2O3 was used as the support, its actual Rh loading amount was the highest, which was close to the design value of 5 %, and its HTDC yield was close to 100 %. Then the better catalytic performance was the Rh supported on the support of CeO2 nanoparticles. Although the specific surface area of Rh/γ-Al2O3 was smaller than that of Rh/C and Rh/HZSM-5, its pore volume and pore diameter were significantly larger than those of other carriers, which were conducive to the internal diffusion of active components and reactants. Despite the large pore size of Rh/CeO2 and Rh/ZrO2, the specific surface area was significantly lower than Rh/γ-Al2O3 and the anchoring metal active sites were fewer, resulting the poor catalytic activity. To characterize the adsorption capacity of Rh ions on the carriers surface, 1 g supports were added to the aqueous solution of rhodium trichloride (100 mg·L−1) respectively, and they were adsorbed at 30 °C for 24 h and then filtered. The concentration of Rh in solution before and after adsorption was analyzed by ICP-AES. As shown in Fig. 4, the adsorption capacity of different carriers for Rh ions in the solution was significantly different. Compared with other carriers, γ-Al2O3 was obviously higher adsorption capacity for Rh, reaching more than 96 %. However, the concentration of Rh ions in treatment solution before and after adsorption was little changed when CeO2 and HZSM-5 were used as carriers, and only about 5 % Rh ions could be adsorbed, indicating these carriers had negligible adsorption capacity for Rh ions. About 68 % of Rh ions in the solution were adsorbed by CeO2 (nm), which was better than 37 % of Rh ions on the activated carbon. This was consistent with the results of catalyst Rh concentration in Table 2. Fig. 5 shows the XRD patterns of different supports. There were no obvious Rh characteristic peaks for all catalysts, indicating that Rh was in an amorphous or highly dispersed state. Compared with other supports, the low-crystalline γ-Al2O3 provided a rougher surface texture, a larger specific surface area, and more active sites, resulting in high catalytic activity. 3.4 Effect of Rh loading on the yield of HTDC The hydrogenation performance of TDC to HTDC over Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh loadings was investigated, as shown in Fig. 6. 1 %Rh/γ-Al2O3 had almost no catalytic activity in the reaction time. The HTDC yield of 3 %Rh/γ-Al2O3 was 41.5 % at 65 min. When the loading of Rh was increased to 5 %, the yield of HTDC was more than 99 % at 65 min. It was demonstrated that the number of Rh active sites remarkably increased with the increase of the Rh loading, and the hydrogenation rate of TDC increased. Low loading and few active components will result in low reactivity. The fresh and reacted Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh loadings were characterized by various catalyst characterization techniques, and the results are shown in Table 3. The actual metal loadings were determined by ICP-AES. The content of Rh in the fresh 1 %, 3 % and 5 %Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was 0.98 %, 2.94 % and 5.09 %, respectively, and 0.96 %, 2.91 % and 4.94 % after the reaction, indicating that there were almost no Rh loss during the reaction. The pore structure of the catalyst was characterized by BET, and it was found that the specific surface area of the catalyst decreased by 15.2 %, 11.9 % and 11.3 %, respectively, compared with the fresh catalyst after the reaction, and the pore volume and pore size were also reduced. It was thought to be probably due to the organic matter in the reaction system coating the catalyst surface and covering the active sites of the catalyst. The average particle size of Rh nanoparticles was further characterized by TEM. It can be found that the Rh particle size of fresh Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with 1 %, 3 % and 5 % Rh loadings was 0.97 nm, 1.43 nm and 1.49 nm, respectively, and 1.01 nm, 1.46 nm and 1.52 nm after the reaction (HRTEM, HAADF and particle size distribution of the catalysts are displayed in Fig. S1). It can be seen that the Rh particle size increased slightly with the increase of Rh loading, but the distribution density increased significantly and the distribution was uniform. The dispersion and particle size of Rh in the catalyst were measured by CO pulse chemisorption (Table S1). With the increase of Rh loading, the dispersion of Rh metal decreased. The possible reason was that there was a strong interaction between Rh species and the carrier on the catalyst with low loading, while the partial agglomeration of Rh species and the increase of particle size on the catalyst with high loading resulted in the decrease of metal dispersion. Finally, the valence state of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was characterized by XPS (Fig. S2 and Table 2). The binding energy range included Rh 3d5/2 and Rh 3d3/2 peaks. Among them, two different Rh 3d5/2 peaks were presented at 307–310 eV, attributed to Rh0 peak at 307.2–307.5 eV and Rh+ peak at 308.5–309.0 eV, respectively [28–30]. It can be seen that the ratios of Rh0/(Rh0 +Rh+) were 78.9 %, 68.9 % and 61.4 % for fresh catalysts with 1 %, 3 % and 5 % loadings, respectively, and there was no significant change after the reaction. 3.5 Deactivation reasons and regeneration methods of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst The reusability of the Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with 5 % Rh loading was investigated, as shown in Fig. 7. Firstly, the catalyst after the first run was filtered without other treatment (Rh/γ-Al2O3-Used), and then used directly. We found that the catalyst was inactive. We eluted the Rh/γ-Al2O3-Used catalyst with DMC (washed at 94 °C for 10 min — filtered, repeated 3 times) and dried (dried at 100 °C for 6 h) to obtain the catalyst Rh/γ-Al2O3-Used-D. Under the same reaction conditions, its catalytic activity was only recovered to 8.0 % of that of fresh catalyst at 95 min, and the yield of HTDC remained unchanged after the reaction time was prolonged to 185 min, indicating that the catalyst was seriously deactivated. In order to determine the causes of catalyst deactivation, the catalysts were characterized by various methods. In the characterization discussion in Section 3.4, it was found that there was almost no loss of Rh before and after the reaction, and no significant change in the valence state of the active center Rh, neither of which was the cause of the catalyst deactivation. It was also found that the pore structure parameters of the catalysts changed significantly before and after the reaction, and it was suspected that the deactivation of the catalysts was related to the obvious reduction of the specific surface area. The pore structure parameters of fresh, deactivated and DMC-eluted Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were further investigated, as shown in Table 4. It could be seen that the specific surface area and pore volume of the deactivated catalyst decreased by 11.3 %, 11.1 % and 6.2 %, respectively, compared with that of the fresh catalyst, but the specific surface area of the catalyst after eluted with DMC could be recovered to more than 96 %. This illustrated that the organics covering the surface of the active sites could be dissolved by DMC. Elemental analysis showed that there was almost no C in the fresh catalyst, but the content of C in the deactivated catalyst reached 8.09 %, which dropped significantly to 0.47 % after being eluted by DMC, which also indicated that the presence of organics caused the deactivation of the catalyst. However, the initial activity could not be completely recovered only by DMC elution and drying treatment, suggesting that there were still organic matter residue in the depth of the catalyst pores. The structure of the organic compounds covering the catalyst surface was determined by XRD. Fig. 8 showed the crystal structure of the fresh and deactivated catalyst. The deactivated catalyst Rh/γ-Al2O3-Used had diffraction peaks at 2θ = 10–30°, which was obviously different from other catalysts, and it was mainly the characteristic diffraction peak of the product HTDC, indicating that the product HTDC covered the surface of the catalyst. Thermogravimetric analysis of the catalyst also indicated the presence of organics on the catalyst surface. The TG curves of fresh and deactivated catalysts under air atmosphere were gathered in Fig. 9. The weight loss of fresh Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was basically unchanged in the 10–800 ℃ temperature range. The deactivated catalyst had a slow weight loss before 120 ℃, which was attributed to the desorption of physically adsorbed water and solvent on the catalyst surface. There were two continuous weight loss processes in the range of 120–300 ℃ and 300–500 ℃, respectively. The former one was caused by the combustion and decomposition of low-boiling organic matter adsorbed on the catalyst surface while the latter one was due to the removal of high-boiling organic matter. The content of Rh metal elements in fresh and deactivated Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was analyzed by ICP-AES. The results showed that the Rh content of the fresh catalyst was 5.09 %, and that of the deactivated catalyst was 4.94 %. There was almost no loss of Rh, excluding the possibility of Rh loss leading to deactivation. In summary, the reversible deactivation of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was caused by the adsorption of organic matter on the catalyst surface and covering the active metals during the reaction process. To this end, the deactivated catalyst was further calcined and regenerated on the basis of DMC elution and drying, and the results are shown in Fig. 10. After calcination at 450 ℃ for 4 h, the catalytic activity of Rh/γ-Al2O3-Used-D-C-4 h catalyst could be recovered to 81 % of that of the fresh catalyst when the reaction temperature was 100 ℃ and H2 pressure was 3 MPa for 185 min. Extending the calcination time to 8 h, the catalyst (Rh/γ-Al2O3-Used-D-C-8h) could be fully regenerated under the same reaction conditions for 95 min. The above results indicated that the Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was deactivated after the reaction, but the activity could be completely recovered by DMC elution, drying and calcination. 4 Conclusion The supported Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst had excellent catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of TDC benzene ring to HTDC. The yield of HTDC was close to 100 % under the optimized conditions of a reaction temperature of 100 °C, a hydrogen pressure of 3 MPa and a time of 65 min. However, the rapid deactivation of the catalyst was also a significant problem. During the reaction, the organic matter overlay on the surface of the catalyst and covered the active metal, which was the main reason for the deactivation of the catalyst. But the deactivated catalyst can be regenerated by solvent elution, drying and high temperature calcination. coredata.dc:description: Methylcyclohexane diisocyanate (HTDI) is the core raw material for the synthesis of high-grade polyurethane. Aiming at the problems existing environmental pollution and safety risks in the phosgene process, a novel and green synthesis route of HTDI was proposed. We studied the catalytic hydrogenation of dimethyl toluene dicarbamate (TDC) benzene ring to methyl cyclohexyldicarbamate (HTDC) in this novel route. The effects of metal active components, supports and metal Rh loadings on the catalytic performance were investigated. It was found that the supported Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst had excellent catalytic activity and selectivity. The yield of HTDC was close to 100 % at 100 °C under 3 MPa hydrogen pressure. However, the catalyst was deactivated seriously after the reaction. The organic matter adsorbed on the catalyst surface and covered the active metal was the main reason for the catalyst deactivation. Fortunately, the deactivated catalyst could be regenerated by solvent washing and high temperature calcination.
coredata.dc:title: A novel and green synthesis of methylcyclohexane diisocyanate: Reaction properties, deactivation and regeneration of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in benzene ring selective hydrogenation
